qas.question: Leibniz describes space as existing only as a relation between what?
According to Leibniz, what has no existence apart from the existence of objections?
What provides the absolute frame of reference within which objects can have motion?
In Newton's system, how does the frame of reference exist between objects within it?
For how long did the evidence of a concave water surface hold authority in reference to space?
What does space exist independently from?
What exists as a relationship between space and objects?
What provides the absolute frame of refrence for space?
What is dependent on the frame of refrence in Newtonian space?

plausible_answers.text: evidence of a concave water surface

context: Leibniz describes a <a1_0>space<a1_0/> that exists only as a relation between <a0_0><b5_0>objects<b5_0/><a0_0/>, and which has no existence apart from the existence of those objects. <b6_0>Motion<b6_0/> exists only as a relation between those objects. <a2_0><b7_0>Newtonian space<b7_0/><a2_0/> provided the absolute frame of reference within which objects can have motion. In Newton's system, the frame of reference exists <a3_0>independently<a3_0/> of the <b8_0>objects contained within it<b8_0/>. These objects can be described as moving in relation to space itself. For <a4_0>many centuries<a4_0/>, the <b9_0>evidence of a concave water surface<b9_0/> held authority.
